1202217.post_content:
Congratulations! You have successfully completed Internationalization.

Now that you have a grasp of OOP and how it works, you're ready to get started applying your new knowledge to WordPress plugins.

You can now proceed to the Final Challenge.

1.title: Introduction
1.description:
You have almost completed WordPress Development for Intermediate Users!

In order to finish the course, you are encouraged to complete a self-assessed challenge. There’s also a final discussion where you can ask any questions of course faciliators while completing the challenge.

Good luck!

1234626.post_content:
Your final task is to complete one of the two challenges below.

Whichever challenge you decide to complete, it must include the following:

  • Well-written PHP and HTML that conforms to the WordPress coding standards
  • Internationalization of any text output in the front-end or admin screens
  • Any hooks or functions you create must have unique names with prefixes

Using the knowledge you have learned throughout this course, ensure your work:

  • Meets the brief in full
  • Uses the correct code (functions, hooks, classes etc.)
  • Quality of code - it must be efficient, clearly written with comments and it must work!
  • Correct use of i18n functions

Challenge Option 1: Theme Templates and the Customizer

  1. Create a simple plugin to register a custom post type.
  2. Create a child theme of the Twenty Sixteen Theme.
  3. In your child theme, create a template file to display archives for your post type and another template file to create single posts of your post type. Make sure the template files are different from the default twenty sixteen ones in some way (e.g. in the way you display metadata, what’s in the loop).
  4. Create an include file in your theme to add Customizer functionality, Create a Color section for the Customizer, that lets people change the color of one or more elements of your theme (this could be headings, links, anything you want).

Challenge Option 2: Queries, Widgets and/or Shortcodes

  1. Create a plugin to register a custom post type.
  2. In your plugin, create a custom query to output the latest five posts of your post type (you can choose what goes in the loop but it shouldn’t include the entire post content)
  3. In an include file in your plugin, create EITHER a widget OR a shortcode so that users can add your query in their posts or pages or via a widget.
  4. Add parameters to your widget or shortcode so that users can specify how many posts are
    output (and anything else you’d like to add).

When you submit your assignment, please provide the following:

  • The plugin file(s)
  • If you’ve created a shortcode, information on the shortcode and its parameters - in other words, how do I use it?

Once you’ve completed your chosen challenge, move on to the final discussion and share with other students and course facilitators how you went completing this final part of the course.

Good luck!

1202219.post_content:
Welcome to the final discussion for WordPress Development for Intermediate Users!

In this course, we step things up a notch to really test your skills! You learned how to:

  • Develop a WordPress theme with include files, template parts, template tags, plus action and filter hooks
  • Add Customizer functionality to your theme
  • Develop plugins using best practice for coding
  • Add complex, custom queries and loops to your themes and plugins
  • Create and work with custom post types
  • Work with metadata, including post metadata (or custom fields) and other metadata e.g. author metadata, and
  • Translate your code and get it ready for release

If you have any questions or concerns about the final assignment, course facilitators are on hand to answer any questions below.

This is your last opportunity to ask any questions you may have about the course content and chat with fellow students. Once you click through to the next screen, you will complete the course.
